conclusion: Determine the heat absorbed by the gas as it transitions from state A to state B.
Volume increases from V0 to 2V0; pressure remains constant at pA = p0.
Work done by the gas is W = p ΔV; given W = 10 J, p = p0, ΔV = V0.
Change in internal energy for an ideal gas depends on temperature change: ΔU = nCv ΔT.
AB is parallel to the V-axis and temperature increases.
Since BC is a straight line through the origin, it implies an isothermal process for BC.
Volume doubles, using V/T = constant at constant pressure: T_B = 2T_0.
Temperature change from A to B is ΔT = T0.
ΔU = nCv T0.
First law of thermodynamics: ΔU = Q - W.
Q = ΔU + W.
Q = nCv T0 + 10.
Ideal gas law: pV = nRT.
At state A, p0V0 = nRT0; at state B, p0 · 2V0 = nR · 2T0.
For a monoatomic ideal gas, Cv = 3/2 R.
nCv T0 = 3/2 nRT0 = 3/2 p0V0.
Given p0V0 = 10 J, nCv T0 = 15 J.
Final calculation: Q = 15 J + 10 J = 25 J.
The heat absorbed by the gas during the process from state A to state B is 25 J.
